user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_bus_finish:
```c
void metal_linux_bus_finish(void)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus;
	struct metal_bus *bus;

	for_each_linux_bus(lbus) {
		if (metal_bus_find(lbus->bus_name, &bus) == 0)
			metal_bus_unregister(bus);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_linux_bus_finish:
#define for_each_linux_bus(lbus) for((lbus)=linux_bus;(lbus)->bus_name;(lbus)++)
...
struct linux_bus {
	struct metal_bus	bus;
	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus	*sbus;
}
...
#define for_each_linux_bus(lbus) for((lbus)=linux_bus;(lbus)->bus_name;(lbus)++)
...
int metal_bus_find(const char *name, struct metal_bus **result)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_bus *bus;

	metal_list_for_each(&_metal.common.bus_list, node) {
		bus = metal_container_of(node, struct metal_bus, node);
		if (strcmp(bus->name, name) == 0 && result) {
			*result = bus;
			return 0;
		}
	}
	return -ENOENT;
}
...
int metal_bus_unregister(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	metal_list_del(&bus->node);
	if (bus->ops.bus_close)
		bus->ops.bus_close(bus);
	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "unregistered %s bus\n", bus->name);
	return 0;
}
...
int metal_bus_register(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	if (!bus || !bus->name || !strlen(bus->name))
		return -EINVAL;
	if (metal_bus_find(bus->name, NULL) == 0)
		return -EEXIST;
	metal_list_init(&bus->devices);
	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.bus_list, &bus->node);
	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "registered %s bus\n", bus->name);
	return 0;
}
...
void metal_sys_finish(void)
{

	/* Shutdown IRQ handling */
	metal_linux_irq_shutdown();
	metal_linux_bus_finish();
	close(_metal.pagemap_fd);

}
...
void metal_finish(void)
{
	if (--_metal.common.ref_count != 0)
		return;

	metal_sys_finish();
	memset(&_metal, 0, sizeof(_metal));
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
int metal_bus_find(const char *name, struct metal_bus **result)
{
	struct metal_list *node;
	struct metal_bus *bus;

	metal_list_for_each(&_metal.common.bus_list, node) {
		bus = metal_container_of(node, struct metal_bus, node);
		if (strcmp(bus->name, name) == 0 && result) {
			*result = bus;
			return 0;
		}
	}
	return -ENOENT;
}
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No unreachable code in this function. All statements can be executed: the success branch (return 0) is reachable when callers pass a non-NULL result (e.g. metal_linux_bus_finish calls metal_bus_find(..., &bus)), and the final return -ENOENT is taken when no match is found or if result is NULL. However, there is a logic bug: the condition if (strcmp(...) == 0 && result) prevents the function from returning success when called with result == NULL. As a consequence, calls like metal_bus_register(bus) that call metal_bus_find(bus->name, NULL) will always get -ENOENT even if the bus exists, allowing duplicate registrations. This is a functional defect but not a MISRA Rule 2.1 (unreachable code) violation.
